facts.text: Appellant lives in a village close to Goa.
Incident took place on November 27, 1960 when Goa was Portuguese territory not part of India.
Deputy Superintendent of Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum received information that contraband goods would be found in appellant's house and raided it in company of three panchas.
Appellant was not present during raid; his mother and sister-in-law were there.

Search revealed in loft: big steel trunk containing belt with four pouches having four gold bars (weight 343 tolas) with foreign marks and labels of Goa Customs authorities, large sum of money, three small cut pieces of gold; cane-box and another steel trunk contained various sums of money.
Appellant arrested on November 30, 1960 and interrogated by Deputy Superintendent of Customs and Excise; answers reduced to writing, read over to him, and signed.
In statement, appellant admitted four gold bars given to him on November 27, 1960 morning by Vittal Morajkar of Goa to deliver back at Belgaum motor-stand or nearby, and he kept them in house.
Gold was foreign gold; import into India forbidden under notification s.8(1) Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947 except with RBI permission.
Prosecuted on complaint by Assistant Collector of Central Excise and Land Customs, Goa Frontier Division, Belgaum under s.167(81) Sea Customs Act r/w s.9 Land Customs Act.
Magistrate convicted appellant, sentenced to imprisonment and fine, ordered confiscation of four gold bars.
Sessions Judge acquitted appellant relying on Calcutta High Court in Sitaram Agarwala v. State.

State appealed to Mysore High Court; HC set aside acquittal, restored Magistrate's conviction and sentence, holding appellant liable under s.167(81) even if not directly concerned with import, relying on appellant's statement and other evidence.
Mysore High Court granted certificate to appeal to Supreme Court on two questions of law.

legal_issues.text: Whether interpretation of s.167(81) Sea Customs Act by Mysore High Court (holding liable even persons not directly concerned with import of prohibited goods) differing from Calcutta High Court in Sitaram Agarwala is correct.
Whether statement made by appellant to Deputy Superintendent of Customs and Excise admissible in evidence in view of s.25 Indian Evidence Act (is such officer a police officer?).

petitioner_arguments.text: Interpretation of s.167(81) Sea Customs Act by Calcutta HC in Sitaram Agarwala correct; appellant not liable if not directly concerned with import.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Sitaram Agarwala v. State (1962 Cr LJ 43)

petitioner_arguments.text: Deputy Superintendent of Customs and Central Excise is police officer within s.25 Evidence Act (broad view: officers with investigation powers); statement inadmissible confession.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Raja Ram Jaiswal v. State of Bihar (1964 2 SCR 752); Nanoo Sheikh Ahmed v. Emperor (1927 ILR 51 Bom 78)

petitioner_arguments.text: Confessional statement obtained by threats (s.24 Evidence Act).

respondent_arguments.text: s.167(81) Sea Customs Act covers persons not directly concerned with import.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sachidananda Bannerjee v. Sitaram Agarwal (1966 2 SCR 1)

respondent_arguments.text: Customs/Excise officer not police officer under s.25 Evidence Act; statement admissible.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram (1962 3 SCR 338); Radha Kishun Marwari v. King-Emperor (1933 ILR 12 Pat 46)

court_reasoning.text: First issue settled by Sachidananda Bannerjee v. Sitaram Agarwal: Calcutta HC view incorrect; s.167(81) covers persons not directly concerned with import; Mysore HC correct. Appellant counsel concedes guilt on this.

Even assuming broad view of 'police officer' in s.25 Evidence Act, Central Excise Officer under Central Excises and Salt Act 1944 not police officer: main purpose levy/collection of duties; powers of arrest/search/inquiry auxiliary; s.21 gives inquiry powers like police station officer but not deemed officer-in-charge of police station (unlike Bihar Excise Act); no power to submit charge-sheet under CrPC s.173.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Statement admissible; distinguishes Raja Ram Jaiswal (different scheme in Bihar Act); accords with Barkat Ram.

court_reasoning.text: No evidence statement obtained by threats; s.24 not applicable.

holdings.text: s.167(81) Sea Customs Act applies to persons not directly concerned with actual import of prohibited goods.
Central Excise Officer under Central Excises and Salt Act not a 'police officer' under s.25 Evidence Act, even in broad sense; confessional statement admissible.

precedents_cited.relevance: Calcutta HC view on s.167(81) Sea Customs Act held incorrect.

precedents_cited.case_name: Sachidananda Bannerjee, Assistant Collector of Customs v. Sitaram Agarwal
precedents_cited.relevance: Holds s.167(81) covers persons not directly concerned with import.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Punjab v. Barkat Ram
precedents_cited.relevance: Customs officer not police officer under s.25 Evidence Act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Raja Ram Jaiswal v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Excise officer under Bihar Act deemed police station officer; different from Central Excise Act.
Broad view of 'police officer' (powers of investigation).
Narrow view of 'police officer' (properly so-called only).

statutes_cited.name: Sea Customs Act, 1878
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishes persons concerned in import of prohibited goods like gold; covers even those not directly importing.

statutes_cited.name: Land Customs Act, 1924
statutes_cited.relevance: Read with Sea Customs Act for prosecution.

statutes_cited.name: Foreign Exchange Regulation Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Notification prohibits gold import without RBI permission.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Evidence Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: s.25 bars confessions to police officers; s.24 excludes if induced by threat etc.; held applicable.

statutes_cited.name: Central Excises and Salt Act, 1944
statutes_cited.relevance: Punishments for evasion; powers of arrest, search, inquiry; officers not police officers.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Powers borrowed for inquiry; no charge-sheet power for excise officers.

statutes_cited.relevance: Deems excise officer officer-in-charge of police station; distinguished from Central Act.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upheld Mysore High Court's reversal of Sessions Judge's acquittal, restored Magistrate's conviction and sentence under s.167(81) Sea Customs Act r/w s.9 Land Customs Act, holding appellant guilty based on admissible confessional statement.

key_quotes.text: s.167(81) of the Sea Customs Act can also take in persons who may not be concerned the actual import of prohibited goods.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on scope of section, settling conflict.

key_quotes.text: a Central Excise Officer under the Act is not a police officer, even in the broader view mentioned above.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Decides admissibility of confession under s.25 Evidence Act.

key_quotes.text: the appellants conviction is correct and the appeal must be dismissed.
